channel.title: Editing Software + fraps huge file?
channel.description:
Recently I bought a gaming computer and I often make videos so I need some software for windows because I automatically had iMovie on my macbook.
I tried 2 free programs but they were horrible. Then I tried the Sony Vegas 12 trial but they had a watermark every now and then. Does anyone know of software that is either insanely cheap or free and pretty good? I only need it to render in HD 1080p and trim clips a little bit.
Google has been no help so far :( And I would consider a torrent but I don't want to get a virus on my brand new computer lol
EDIT: Okay, and I did like a 10 minute video with fraps on minecraft, and the file size was like 36GB. Something seems very wrong about that. I was recording my mic too but it shouldn't be that big at all. I would have to record my xbox for like 15 hours for 36GB...
And a 15 second video was like 600MB lol

item.title: Editing Software + fraps huge file?
item.dc:creator: @kihomura Kihomura
item.description:
@kihomura wrote:

[quote=“marcbob, post:40, topic:521419”]Just downloaded dxtory. Fraps is less laggy when recording and file sizes are around the same size
Going to check out sony vegas pro now and see if rendering it with that will help a lot.[/quote]
Dxtory should overall have a less performance hit because it’s putting most of the work on the hard drive instead.

Here’s some of my settings:
Codec: Dxtory video codec (YUV410, with compression on)
Framerate: 29.97
Scaling: 100%
(these are pretty much default)

Make sure you have Synchronize Video FPS unticked unless you want to play at 30fps. There’s also many videos on YouTube that give their own settings and whatnot.

Yes, you’re going to get large files with any game recording software and the only way to combat it is to compress it. Fraps records in somewhat lossless quality with few ways to reduce file sizes. One thing you can do is record in half size, which isn’t the greatest solution. Fraps is quite outdated and has been lacking many useful features for years, which is why most people have moved onto different means of recording.

DXTory offers many compression options and you can customize how the footage scales. As mentioned in my previous post, the performance cost is also significantly less.

item.title: Editing Software + fraps huge file?
item.dc:creator: @kihomura Kihomura
item.description:
@kihomura wrote:

Sony Vegas for editing. You don’t really need anything better for YouTube content, let’s be honest.

DXTory for recording. DXTory records all audio to different tracks so you can adjust volume to each track individually later when you’re editing. DXTory also has very little performance impact compared to most capturing software.

If you’re going to record in high quality, you’re going to need a dedicated hard drive that is large and fast. Currently I use a 2tb 7200rpm hard drive for recording 1080p at 30/60fps.
http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B006H32Q3S

A large SSD might be good, but I have also heard about people wrecking their SSDs by writing large files to them. Don’t know how accurate that is.

item.title: Editing Software + fraps huge file?
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

RiiPiiNFtW:

Please don’t get After Effects for video editing. Use it for actual effects… Rendering a 2-3 minute clip takes a good 5+ hours, and it renders in an uncompressed AVI format, which means more space being used and you then have to compress it into another format of AVI and than convert it to be able to upload it to YouTube since they don’t take AVI files.

After effects worked fine for rendering, other than it creating decently big files. I really wish Camtasia would just record the whole fucking screen so i didn’t have to play bf3 in a smaller section of my screen. Camtasia was high quality and came with an editor and probably produced smaller files. Oh well.
